div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1905. JAPAN'S FUTURE.
div.p: The “Times” draws attention to the fact that Count Katsura, the Japanese Premier, has been addressing to the provincial governors he Empire some words which point the way the employment of Japan’s activities in the immediate future. The national energy, he told his hearers, must be so directed as to effect an economic expansion and develop- ment commensurate with the nation's victories. All the efforts which for twenty months have been devoted to the successful prosecution of the war must now be concentrated on carrying out the post bellum programme. It is same policy that Count Okuma was enforcing the other day in the pages of an English contemporary, and it is the only policy that can commend itself to a sagacious Jap- anese statesman. There are signs already that it is beginning to sink into the minds of the pie. The first outburst of excited indigna- tion that greeted the peace terms is giving place to a business-like consideration of the future. The amount of strong feeling which still exists shows the strain that the Japanese have just gone through, and does all the more honor to the self-control and far-sightednees which have enabled the majority to triumph over the first pangs of disappointment.

The first section of the Japanese nation to grasp the rest opportunities which peace has brought within range is, naturally enough, the business community. A piece of intelligence is reported which is in the highest degree signi- cant of the future. A great trade combination, representing eighty-one firms, and headed by the Japanese capitalist Mr. Iwade, has been formed for the promotion of Japan’s industries and the expansion of her foreign trade. We are told that it is based on the support of wealthy and conservative elements; but, though it seems to have plenty of Japanese capital behind it, its organisers have taken Okuma's wise advice, and declare their readiness to co- operate with the capitalists of foreign countries, Korea and China an the chief fields of enter- prise to which the combination is going to de- vote itself. Here, then, we have the first big move- ment to take advantage of the opportunities afforded by the peace. It is directed towards the countries which Japan has thrown open to her own industry, but which she has opened equally to the industry of all the world. In Korea, of course, she has very large commercial interests already. Above and beyond the volume of trade which she offers, Korea is of the utmost importance to Japan as an outlet for her surplus population. The Japanese people now number 60 millions, as against 40 millions in 1890. Expansion and emigration are necessities. To Korea, where many Japanese havee settled, a constant and still larger stream will continue to go, with all the more confidence now that Japan’s predo- minance in the Hermit Kingdom is assured, The development and civilisation of Korea, which Japan has taken in hand already, coupled with the growing settlement of her people in the peninsula, hold oat great prospects of commercial expansion. Bat it is safe to say that all the chances of this kind which Korea offers are inconsiderable beside the measure- less opportunities in China, where Japan, already a powerful factor, will enter with in finitely greater prestige and resources after the war. No one can yet attempt to estimate what will be the effect on China, in many other ways than the merely commercial of the rise of this untiring people at her gates if any Power can prevail on her to shake off her lethargy and enter on the path of reform, it will be the Oriental Power which knows the Chinese mind as no Europeans can hope to know it, and yet is more sin- cere in its dealings with China than are most of them. The terms of the peace and the scope of the new Anglo-Japanese treaty have shown the Chinese that they have nothing in the way of territorial dismemberment to dread from Japan. Nor will they have trade mono- polies, or more “spheres of influence” wrung, out of them ; for Japan fought for the Open Deor, and by the principle of the Open Door she is prepared to stand.

Equal opportunity in the Par Bast has been guaranteed to all nations, but what kind of a people is it which has secured that guarantee Count Katsura made no idle boast when he spoke to the provincial Governors of its "enter- prising energy,” an energy possesed by the Japanese "in so remarkable a degree.” The Japanese have asked nothing better than to be put on a fair level with competing races. They know that, once there, the qualities of intelligence, thoroughness, and vigour will place them ahead of many of their rivals in peace. We have all wondered at the success of martial Japan, bat we mast expect in the ensuing period to see industrial successes of her part which will be no less surprising. She has to retrieve the temporary economic losses of the war, and that conscioousness will lend fresh spar to her at the beginning of her enter prise.

div.head: FRANCE AND VENEZUELA ATTEMPTED NEGOTIATIONS. STRAINED RELATIONS
div.p: Paris, September 25. The relations between France and Venezuela are becoming acuta President Castro recently closed the French cable alleging a breach of contract. M. Taigny. the French charge d’af- faires, is endeavouring to negotiate, but Presi- dent Castro is adopting au arrogant attitude. (Reuter)

div.head: THE HUNGARIAN CRISIS. EMPEROR AND OPPOSITION.
div.p: Budapest, September 25. Intense anger prevails here at the way in which the leaders of the Opposition were received by the Emperor, who received them standing, did not shake hands, and addressed them curtly in German, without giving them an opportunity to speak. He dismissed them in four minutes.

The leaders informed Count Cziraki yester- day morning that they declined to form a Government on the Emperor’s conditions, Count Czraki promised to bring the Emperor’s reply at 2.30 p.m., but when he arrived at the hotel at 3.15 he found that they had already returned to Budapest. (Reuter)
Budapest, September 25. The Hungarian Opposition leaders received great ovation when they returned here. (R.)
Budapest, September 25. Thw disagreement between the Hungarian cabinet and the Emperor is becoming grave. (Havas)

div.head: BRITISH COTTON GROWING. ASSOCIATION CEASES EXPENDITURE.
div.p: London, September 25. The "Westminster Gazette" is informed that the British Cotton Growing Association has been compelled to cease expenditure on new developments and to curtail its expend- ture generally, owing to lack of financial support {Reuter)

div.head: EAST AFRICAN REBELLION. ATTACK ON MAHENGE.
div.p: Berlin, September 25. 350 rebels in German East Africa have been killed in an unsuccessful attack on Mahenge. (Reuter)

div.head: GREECE AND ROUMANIA. THE PRESS INDIGNANT.
div.p: Bukarest. September 25. The newspapers protest against the expulsion of Roumanians from Greece, and threaten to retaliate. The situation is strained. (Havas)

div.head: TARTARS AND ARMENIANS. CONCLUSION OF PEACE.
div.p: Baku. September 25. A conference of the leading Tartars and Armenians has concluded peace. (Reuter)

div.head: JAPS SEIZE MERCHANT SHIP.
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 25. Intelligence has been received that the Japanese have seized a steamer of the Kamt- chatka Trading Company near Behring island, which they occupied afterwards. The name of the Japanese commander and the date of the affair are not stated. (Reuter)

div.head: BRITAIN AND JAPAN. MEETING OP FLEETS.
div.p: Tokio. September 25. As soon as the treaty of peace is ratified the British Squadron and the Japanese fleet will meet in Tokio Bay. (Reuter)

div.head: CONGRESS OF POLAR EXPLORERS.
div.p: Brussels, September 25. The King has initiated a Congress of Polar Explorers to organize international expeditions to both poles. All the leading explorers have given their support to this Congress. (Reuter)

div.head: M. WITTE'S MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Berlin, Septombar 25. M. Witte has had an interview with M. de Richthofen. He will be received by the Empe- ror at the Castle of Rominten on Tuesday. R.) Berlin, September 25. M. Witte visited Prince Von Bulow and then left for Rominten. (Havas)

div.head: THE LATE COUNT BRAZZA
div.p: PariS, September 25. The explorer Brazza was returning to France with the most scathing indictment against M. Gentil, the administrator of the French Congo, for incapacity and maladministration, aS well as for encouraging gross cruelties. (Reuter

div.p: Paris, September 95. The ex-minister Cavaignao is deed. (Reuter)

div.head: A Smuggler Arrested
div.p: An Arab named Mohamad Abdullah was arrested last Sunday for attempting to pass the customs officers with a quantity of tobacco in his possession without declaring it.

div.head: The Bank ok Athens
div.p: We understand that the cashier of the Bank of Athens who was arrester I yesterday on a charge of embez- zlement had misappropriated £1,000 and not £2,000 as was generally reported at the time.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 10 vessels pa sod through the Canal on the 22nd inst, 8 of which were British, 1 German, 1 French. The day’s receipts were frs. 295,1-82.40, making the total from the 1st inst frs. 6,133,032.65.

div.head: Child Burnt to Death
div.p: A little boy of five years of age was playing with a lighted candle in his father's house on Saturday even- ing, when his clothes caught fire. The lad received severe burns, from which he died very shortly after.

div.head: A Gambler’s End
div.p: A Copt named Rusdi Morcos, 33 years of ago, who had misappro- priated gums of money entrustod to his charge and had lost them by gambling, committed suicide on Saturday evening by drinking a quantity of phenic acid.

div.head: Cholera in Russia
div.p: The president of the quarantine board has received information from the Russian sanitary delegate of a fatal case of cholera at Vlatslovosk, Varsovia. The precautionary measures of disinfection and isolation have been taken.

div.head: Fatal Bathing Accident
div.p: A native, Gad Ahmed Ibrahim by name, twenty years of age, was bathing yesterday at El Nafrouzeh, when he suddenly disappeared under water and did not come up again. The body of the un- fortunate youth, was, however, recovered later and taken to the hospital, where an inquest was held previous to interment.

div.head: Army Arabic Examination
div.p: The follow- ing officers of the Egyptian Army have passed the Preliminary Arabic Examination held on the 1st August:—El Bimbashi Hawksley, Artii- ery, El Bimbashi Dyer, D.S.O., Camel Corps, El Bimbashi Lucas, 1st Battalion, El Bimbashi Percival, 11th Sadanase, El Bimbashi Beamish, 12th Sudanese, El Bimbashi Rugg. Medical Corps, El Bimbashi Foster, Medical Corps.

div.head: Fall from a Roof
div.p: A sad accident oc- curred yesterday in the Attarin quarter to a native woman of forty years of age, named Mahbouba bint Ahmed. The un- fortunate woman was at work on the roof of her house, and at the time was occupied in shaking a mat, when she overbalanced herself and fell from the roof to the ground. Her ankle was fractured and it is believed that death must have been almost instantaneous.

div.head: Troops for Egypt
div.p: The transport Duners, which leaves Southampton to morrow, will bring out a large number of troops for Egypt, includ- ing 7 officers and 153 non-commissioned officers and men for the Royal Berkshire Regiment ; 1 officer and 152 noncommissioned officers and men for the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, 1 officer and 56 non commissioned officers and men for the King's Royal Rifles ; 41 men of the Royal Garrison Artill-.ry, besides several details for other corps. The vessel is due at Alexandria on the 8th October.

div.head: For the Calabrian Victims
div.p: We are once more asked to appeal to our readers to support an entertainment for the relief of the victims of the Calabrian earthquake. The committee of the San Stefano Club and H.E. Khalil Pasha Hamada are organising a benefit entertainment, which is to take place on Friday, under the patronage of Baron Acton, diplomatic agent and consul general for Italy, when the children of the members of the committee will perform a ballet "en miniature” on the terrace of the casino. The Bracale orchestra will give a concert, the items of which will be composed entirely of Verdi’s works and the band of the customs porters’ children will also play selections. At the conclusion of the enter- tainment a number of presents will be dis- tributed to the cbildren. Subscribers will not be admitted except on payment of the entrance fee of P.T. 5, and the whole of the receipts will be devoted to the benefit fund. The entertainment will commence at 5 p.m.

div.head: Esbekieh Gardens Theatre
div.p: Judging by the large audience that nightly attend this theatre, the French Operetta company now performing there seem to have become great favorites with the Cairene playgoing public. On Saturday the three act comedy Monsieur le Directeur was played before a crowded and enthusiastic house. Between the second and third acts Mlle Symiane-Val entertained the audience with some songs from her extensive repertoire which elicited hearty applause. Last night the Gardet company gave a special benefit performance for the thousands I who have been rendered destitute by the terrible earthquake in Calabria and the house was crowded in every part. The artistes appear- ed to excel themselves for the occasion and their efforts met with most hearly and well deserved applause. The piece staged was La Marraine de Charley, which evoked much laughter. Daring the third act Madame Bra- cale sang Giordano's "Andre Chenier" and Bizet's "Pecheur dee Perles” in excellent strain, and the ever popular Mile Symiane-Val sang "Sous les Bamboos," "Daos l’Oasis," and "Messanda” with her accustomed vivacity.

div.head: STATE RAILWAYS REPORT. REPLY TO THE COMMISSION.
div.p: The report of the Board of Administration of the State Railways and Telegraphs and the Port of Alexandria is of special interest, appear- ing as it does a few months after the report of the railway commission presided over by Lord Farrar. The chairman and the directors of the board were evidently by no means insensible to the criticisms of Lord Farrar, Mr. Bury and Major Le Breton, and at the conclusion of the report under the heading "General” the reader will find their answer to the commis- sion. So interesting is this reply that we felt that no apology is needed for the reproduction of the more interesting passages of the direc- tors reply in full.

“During the last four months of the year, a rapid and exceptional increase of imports pro- duced an acute crisis in traffic at Alexandria and gave rise to well-founded complaints. We had forseen the possibility of such a crisis, though we had not anticipated so sudden an increase in trade, but we had been unable to obtain funds in sufficient time to prepare for it. Since it occurred, funds have keen placed at our disposal, which are, we believe, sufficient to provide against so serious a crisis in future.

The commission presided over by Lord Far- rer, to which we have alluded, was in Egypt when these difficulties were at their worst, and it was far from easy for our officials to deal with the exceptional stress of traffic and at the same time furnish the commission with the information they desired in a complete and convenient form.

The commission criticised severely our sys- tem of signals. When the present Board took office, they were at once struck by the defects of this system, but owing to the many other works which urgently required attention, and the enquiries and experiments which we con- sidered necessary before embarking on a large expenditure, we did not seriously commence signalling work until 1903, in which year we gave large orders for appliances of the latest types. The erection of these appliances only commenced in 1904, and the commission seems to have based its opinion on installations which were unfinished, or even—as at Kantara, which is cited by them as an example — which had not been commenced.
The reasons which led us to adopt the electro pneumatic system for Cairo station do not appear to have been fully explained to the commission.

The technical member of the commission expressed to us verbally a high opinion of our signal engineer, Naghib Bey Shakour, which we share. We note with pleasure the remarks of the commission on the ability and skill of Mr. Husson, deputy chief engineer, who is entrusted with the difficult task of strengthen- ing the railway bridges.

Finally, we cannot refrain from commenting on the remarks made both in the report of the commission and in the press on the subject of the Permanent Way Department. It is extremely easy to criticise this Department, it is most difficult for any person not intimately concerned in the work to realise the difficulties which have baset Mr. Cotterill's efforts to make good the defects both of organisation and of maintenance which had resulted partly from a long period of insufficient expenditure, partly from other causes which we need not here discuss. Mr. Cotterill has ungrudgingly devoted all his time and energy to the work ; he has done his utmost to ensure economy, to defend the interests of the administration, and to improve the position of his staff, espe- cially of the labouring class. No one acquaint- ed with the alterations made daring his term of office, can fail to recognize the improve- ments effected under his direction.

Much remains to be done, and we have been obliged to consider the desirability of appoint- ing a succesor to him, whose powers have not been affected by so long a period of work under trying conditions; but we feel certain that if he leaves our service, his own staff and many in this country who have been brought into contact with him, will join in our sincere regret at his departure."

Whatever view be taken of the defence as a whole, (and it is certain to give rise to some discussion) we feel sure that the references to Mr. Cotterill contained in the last two para- graphs will be thoroughly appreciated by all who have had an opportunity of watching Mr. Cotterill's work or of studing his schemes for the benefit of the lower ranks of his staff and their children.

div.p: Owing to the annual acquatic sports of the Alexandria Swimming Club taking place on Saturday, 7th October, there will be no shoot- ing on that day, the B.R C. Cup competition being postponed until Saturday. 14th October next.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CRICKET CLUB.
div.p: The season of the Alexandria Cricket Club will he closed on Satarday by a match between earns composed of members who are over and those who are under 29 years of age.

div.head: THE CHATHAM EXPLOSION. TRANSPORT OF BLASTING MATERIAL.
div.p: A special train arrived at Alexandria from Aboukir shortly after 1 am. yesterday. The train which had been specially chartered by Messrs. Thos Cook and Sons was in charge of Hr. Harold Harris, P.C.S., the well-known expert employed by Messrs. Nobel, and con- tained twenty-two cases of blasting gelatine with other accessories which are to be employ- ed in the blowing np of the SS. Chatham which will take place on Thursday. These cases, which had been stored at Aboukir, were naturally handled with great care by all who were responsible for their conveyance to the train and officials of the Railway Admi- nistration were also on board the "special" to supervise the operation and the transport of the cases to Alexandria. In the evening the train left Alexandria station with Mr. Harris on board for Ras-el-Esh,a station fourteen kilo metres south of Port Said, near which the electric batteries which will ignite the charges that are to explode the Chatham are to be put into place. Special precautions have been taken against any accident happening to the train which conveys the explosive charges.

We hear that no great danger is apprehended by the most competent judges from the wave that will follow the explosion. They hold that, the banks of the canal near the scene of the explosion being low, a great quantity of the water displaced will sweep, over them and dissipate its force instead of rushing violently up and down the canal as it would do were the banks high and solid.

A certain amount of inconvenience will be caused to the public by the rupture of tele- graphic communication between Port Said and the rest of Egypt, and we wonder whether it would be possible for the Government and the Eastern Telegraph Company to come to an ar- rangement by which the submarine cable from Port Said to Alexandria could be used for messages to other parts of Egypt during the interval between the explosion and the restor- ation of telegraphic communication.

div.head: SHIP ASHORE IN SUEZ GULF. ( From our Correspondent ).
div.p: Suez, Monday. The Anchor liner Nubia from Liverpool bound to Calcutta with general cargo ran ashore yesterday in the Suez gulf at Ras Shukhair, fifteen miles south of Ras Garib lighthouse.
It is however expected she will come off after discharging cargo from the forehold, and for this purpose assistance will be sent from Suez to night.

div.head: THE LATE MR. HANSARD.
div.p: The late Mr. R. M. Hansard's funeral which took place at the Cairo cemetery on Sunday at 4.30 p.m. was attended by Col. Atkin- son, Capt. Lidlow, Capt. Pearson, Messrs. E. M. Dowson, W. B. Trelawoy, J. Craig, L. B. Weldon, G. R. Smith, Robert Bey, Dr J. Ball, II. J. Boadnell, J. Kearney, B. F. Keeling, A. Lucas, Ch. Seiuerth, S. H. Trim an, F. Wilshire, T. D. Scott, Grahame, Harle, Man-field, Da Cosson, Dr J. Garner, Tatton Brown, Muntz etc. etc, and all the Survey staff (including many native employes).
The funeral service was conducted by the Very Rev. Dean Butcher.

Wreaths were sent by Capt. and Mrs. Lyons, Lieat. Col. and Mrs. Atkinson, Capt. H. D. Pear sou, Mr. and Mrs. J. F. G. Hopkins, Mr. E. M. Dowson and Mr, W. B. Trelawny, Mr. and Mrs. L. B. Weldon. Mr. and Mrs. Craig, the printing office, Survey Dept., the topographical 'office and„"His colleagues in Upper Egypt."

div.head: MOTORS FOR THE SUDAN.
div.p: The Sirdar has been for some time trying to solve the problem of desert locomotion by the introduction of a quicker mode of transport than the camel in those, districts which are not served by the railway. The motor-car which has been constructed specially for Sir Reginald Wingate for the purposes of desert travel was finally tested before the departure of the Sirdar for Egypt last week on the sands at Dunbar. While the car came well out of the trials it is doubtful whether a motor can be constructed that would be powerful enough to drag the 1 1/2 ton dead weight of the trailer, as the sandbanks of the Sudan would place a heavy strain on the machinery. The car when last tried ploughed through the soft sand at the rate of three miles an hour; on the harder aand seven miles was the average, and when relieved of the trailer excellent progress was made.

It will be interesting to know at what rate of progression the same car can be propelled over the loose sandy soil of the greater part of the desert, and whether this specially built motor will turn out a success, for, if so, the problem will have been solved.

div.head: BECK and CO’S PILSENER BEER
div.p: Bremen Obtainable from every respectable firm In Cairo, Alexandria, and the Sudan Otherwise apply to, E.J Fleurent F. Micallif

div.head: NOTABLE DENOUNCED. BASELESS ACCUSATION.
div.p: A certain Abdallah Sadik recently informed the Slave Trade Department that Lamloum Bey El Saadi, a notable of Maghagha, who rendered considerable services of a quasi-di- plomatic nature to the Government this year, had brought four black slaves with him from the frontier of Tripoli, which he visited in March.

On receiving this denunciation the Depart- ment sent an inspector to visit the Bey's ezbeh at Maghagha. The black slaves proved to be free laborers working for a daily wage, abso- lutely without complaint and, in fine, enjoying what Mr. Edward Lear describes as "truly abject and rustic happiness.” The Bey, who was justly indignant at the accusation stated that he bad been sent on a mission to the frontier of Tripoli and had there settled a number of questions that had arisen from Bedouin quarrels, and finding Sudanese slaves there had persuaded them to accompany him to Egypt, after obtaining manumission documents from the Ottoman Government which were countersigned by the British Con- sul. The Bey having thus emerged from the enquiry without a stain on his character Abd- allah Sadik remains to be dealt with. We hope to hear of his appearance in the dock one of these days.

div.head: THE MENZALEH CANAL CO.
div.p: It is now expected that the channel across the lake will be completed by the end of next month,and it is proposed that Sir John Rogers, the chairman of the company, who returns to Cairo in about a month’s time, will inaugurate the new passengers and goods service between Port Said and Matarieh in the first week of November. The Matarieh and Damietta section will then be taken in hand and it is hoped that the dredging operations of the whole distance of about 30 kilometres will be finished in six months. When this has been accomplish- ed the company will then undertake the widening of the Ananieh canal near Damietta, which is 6 1/4 kilometres long, and by means of a lock gate, make it navigable for small steamers, which will then be able to go through from Port Said to Mansourah by the Nile. This work will also greatly facilitate the transport of coal from the former port to all the places on the river.

div.head: THE HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE.
div.p: We learn on good authority that a meeting of the directors of the Hambarg-Amerika and Anglo-American Companies will be held in London in the course of next week when it is expected that a decision will be arrived at between the two companies with regard to a joint tourist service on the Nile. As we have already informed our readers the German com- pany intended starting a rival line of river steamers to run in opposition to the two ser- vice already long established but, from what we hear the negotiations that have been going on through the summer are likely to be brought soon to a satisfactory conclusion.

div.head: THE NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
div.p: The above company has just concluded the sale of the estate purchased from the Daira Sanieh about a year and a half ago at Mataana in Upper Egypt; the price at which it has been sold will leave a net profit of £50,000 to the company. The estate consists of some 3,450 feddans, the greater part of which is under cultivation, and gives a revenue of nearly £9,000 per annum, which represents about 6% on the purchase price.

The board of directors in London have decided upon paying a dividend of ten per cent on the called up capital at the end of next month. This is the first distribution to be made since the formation of the company in 1899.

div.head: STOCK EXCHANGE SETTLEMENTS
div.p: The London Stock Exchange Committee has appointed Wednesday, September 27, a special settling day in— Egyptian Gold and Gam Syndicate, Limited — 6,623 Vendors’ Shares of £l each fully paid, Nos 28,371 to 34,993. Sudan Goldfield, Limited - 145,000 Vendors’ Shares of £1 each fully paid, Nos. 1 to 145,000.

div.head: COAL ASSOCIATION.
div.p: We understand that the majority of the members of the Coal Association of Alexandria favor a stoppage on the same lines as that which recently disturbed the Genoa market and was caused by the dilatoriness of the Italian Government in remedying the deficiency of the State Railways in waggon supplies.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY.
div.p: At its meeting of last Saturday the execu- time committee of the Khedivial Agricultural Society decided to establishing seven large depots of chemical manures in the principal centres of Lower Egypt and appoint store keepers to have the charge of these depots. It was also derided to hold the usual agriculture show at Cairo in the first fortnight of February. The Mansourah show was put off a week to avoid dashing with the Leilat-al-Mirag feast in the middle of the Moslem month of Shaaban.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. H. the Khedive left Constantinople yesterday and will arrive at Alexandria on Thursday.
Boutros Pasha Ghali arrived at Alexandria this morning by the Messagaries Maritime until boat.
Mrs. and Miss Bullock are returning to Egypt by the troopship Donera, leaving Southampton to-morrow.
El Kaimakam D. K. E. Hall Bey, Government, and El Bimbashi H. M Travers, 10th Sudanese, have resigned their commis- sions in the Egyptian Army.
Captain C. K. Morgan, R.A.M.C., has been granted leave of abscooe until December 21.
Dr. Warnock, resident medical superinten- dent of the Abbasieh Lunatic Asylum, is expected to return to Cairo from England at the end of this month.

H. I. M. the Shah of Persia has been gra- ciously pleased to bestow the order of com- mander of the 3rd Class of the Lion and Sun upon Mr. C. Meimarachi, managing direotor of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd.
We are pleased to announce that Dr. Charles Faber, American Dentist of Cairo, will shortly open an office in Davies Bryan’s new building for the practice of his profession.

The news comes from Vienna that Mr. Bea- man, correspondent of the "Standard” at the Austrian capital has met with a slight accident Mrs. Beaman, who has been staying at Ther- pia, has left for Vienna with Mile Sophie Corpi.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice:—Capt Ladmouth, Mr. and Mrs. W. W. D. Tweddie, Miralai O’Connell Bey, Kaimakam Percival Bey, Vi- comte and Vicomtease de Fontarce, M. Atorff, Mr. A. Baker, Ayruth Bey and family, Miss Miller, Miss Reimer, Mr. Walther, Mi. B. Joseph, Hogg Bey, Rev. and Mrs. Cooke Collie Smith, M. Siess, M. Histhemann.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: APPEAL TO THE SOCIETE ARTISTIQUE.
div.p: To the Editor or the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—As the open season draws near I allow myself to ask the Societe Artistique if this year we will again be bereft of one of the finest modern operas, and only for a political difference. Yes political!! strange as it seems. But what have politics to do with art,. and pa- triotism with music?

It is Germania that I mean, that splendid opera that we had the happy chance of seeing staged two years ago, interpreted by cele- brated artists such as Anoona, Garbin, and Santerelli, not forgetting Walter Carlo and Emma Trentini.

The piece was new, the music rather diffi- cult, worthy of Wagner himself, but little by little the artistic ear of the Egyptian public relished the masterful and harmonious "airs” of Germania and the eye became more and more interested in its everchanging scenes.
Alexandria especially was enthusiastic. In every corner one spoke but of Germania and the "Gaudeamus igitur" was whistled by young and old. But then came the reaction.

Some found themselves piqued in their patriotism, especially by the last scene in which Napoleon’s army is seen retreating before the Germans, and loud was their outcry, that such a piece could be played in a land like ours. I say "some" and happily there were not many.
This year La Belliucioni will once more favor us with her presence! What a splendid "Ricke” she would be, and we all hope to see her in this part.
Let politics be politics and art remain art. One has nothing to do with the other.—I am, Sir, etc.

div.head: TRIBUNAL DES CONTRAVENTIONS
Un Cas uk Peste.
div.p: Le 18 courant est venue per devant la tri- bunal mixte des contraventions a Alexandrie l’affeire du Dr. Varveropoulo, mis en contra vention pour n'avoir pas déclaré un cas de peste qu’il avait au à soigner.
L’audience était présidée par le Com. G. Paulucci; Zaki bey Ghali remplissait les fonc- tions de substitut du procurear général et M. Ch. Camiolo celles de greffier.

Après la leetare da procès-verbal de contra veation/lMa Narissi, avocat da dootear oontre venant, prit la parole pour exposer la défense de son olient. L'iospactaqr sanitaire, U. le Dr. Gottschlich, interrogé par le prérident, fit la déposition suivante :—

“Je ne connais pas le Dr. Varveropoulo. Le 5 août, j'ai été appelé par le Dr. Mohamed Aly Zarka, médecin du kism Karmous, pour inspecter un cadavre qui avait eu un ou de peste. Le décédé s’appelait Mohamed Issa. La constatation a été faite entre 10 et 11 heures du matin.

“Quelques jours avant ce fait, il y avait en un eu de peste au quartier Kom-el-Nadoura, et à la suite de ce cas nous nous sommes mis en garde de ne pas délivrer de certificat d'inhu- mation sansavoir d'abord procédé à une consta- tation médicale. Moi et le docteur Zarka syant dono procédé à cette constatation, nous avons trouvé sur la personne du cadavre de Mohamed Issa ungros bubon de peste. Pour moi, iln’yapas le moindre doute que o'était un cas de peste ce n’était pas une gastro-entérite, comme il a été qualifié par le docteur Varveropoulo. D'après nos constatations il ne pouvait y avoir d'erreur sur le diagnostic."

Sur la demande dU président, il répond : "Depais plusieurs années, la Municipalité m’a fait l'honneur de me nommer son inspec- teur sanitaire et pendant tout ce temps, j’ai en l'occasion de constater plusieurs centaines de cas de peste, sur lesquels il m'était presque impossible de me tromper.

“La gastro-entérite ne produit jamais de bubons ; c'est la scrofuleuse qui peut en pro- duire. Je crois que le Dr. Varveropoulo ne pouvait pu se tromper. Il a mis une très grande négligencs dans la constatation. Le fait des bubons a été oonstaté, comas je l’ai déja dit, en présence du Dr. Zarka."

Sur demande de M. le président au témoin, si on avait procédé a l'autopsie du cadavre, il répond : “j’ai cru inutile de faire une au topsie, ni un examen bactériologique parce que lo -as de peste était tout b fait oûdr comme aspect du cadavre et d'ailleurs confirmé par h fait que cet homme provanait d'un four sis l Karmous, oü la veille il y avait eu un autre cas de pesto. Il y a eu aussi d'autres eu de peste au quartier Labbaue.
Comme les assertions du Dr. Gottachlich étaient contestées par Me Narissi, le tribunal décida de nommer comme expert M. le Dr Torella.

L’affaire a été plaidée hier. Le rapport da Dr. Torella conclut a ce qu’il n'y a pu le moindre doute qu'on se trouve en face d'un cas de peste. Le Dr. Gottschlich a confirmé pure ment et simplemeut set assertions précédentes. Le Dr. Zarka, médecin du kism Karmous, qui avait constaté en compagnie da Dr. Gottschlich que le éfunt Mohamed Issa avait un bubon inguinal et des taches de peste sur le corps, a également affirmé qu’il a’agissait indubitable ment d’un ou de peste.
Sur ces dires le ministère public a conclu a la condamnation du Dr. Varveropoulo au ma ximum de la peine, soit a 100 PT. d’amende et 7 jours de prison.
Me. Narissi a prononcé eu faveur de soi client one longue et brillante plaidoierie dont voici un conrt aperça :

En Jait : M. le Dr. Varveropoulo, appelé a soigner le défont, Mohamed Issa, constata qu’il était atteint de gastro-antérite aigue qui pro voquait des vomissements et da la diarrhée Il ordonna une potion qui ne fut pas prise par le malade et quelque tempe après une seconde visite que le Dr lui fit la mort survint Or dans les deux visites faites par le Dr Varveropoulo celui-ci-ne trouva sur lui aucun signe de peste Ce n'est pas, cependant, la compétence qui lui manque, puisqu'il a eu l’occasion de soigner plusieurs cas de peste a Damanhour. Il y a dono deux opinions en présence, celle da Di Gotablich et celle da Dr Varveropoulo. Ceci étant admis, il est juste de prendre note dam là déclaration da Dr Gotschlich que celui-ci n'a procédé a aucun examen bactériologique, seule preuve qui eût été légale et irréfutable. Le Dr Torella,nommé comme expert pour tran- cher la question, s’est prononcé, il est vrai, et faveur de l’inspecteur sanitaire, mais sans ap- porter aucun fait nonveau, ni aucune preuve Son témoignage est d'autant plus sujet b oau tion qu’il semblo professer pour le Dr Gotsohlicl nne espèce de culte, analogue au fétichisme. Laissant de côté l'opinion da Dr Torella, il y a cependant un moyeu de tout concilier: o’est que les taches et les bubons n’apparaissant souvent qu’après la décès, lorsque le cours de la maladie a été très rapide, il est bien difficile dans ce cas pont le Dr d’établir le diagnostic de la peste.

En droit : On se trouva en face d’un procès- verbal dont la véracité est contestés; et comme ici, il ne s’agit pu de faits dont l’existence on la non-existence peuvent être prouvées par appréciation mais qui doivent être dûment et légalisent établies par des procédés indiscuta- bles, le prévenu ne pent pu être obligé d’ap- porter la preuve du contraire. Si, en outre, le procès-verbal de l’officier de santé peut être considéré comme infaillible, lorsqu'il s’agit d’ur diagnostic facile et fréquent, il n’en est pas de même en ce qui concerne la peste, maladie rare et au diagnuestic excessivement difficile, qui ne se trouve vérifie que dans la pro- portion de 5 our cent et encore grace a l'examen bactériologique. On voit pu là que pour valoir légalement un procès-verbal ne doit pu se baser en pareil cas sur un examen superficiel mais sur un examen bactériologique sérieux. La preuve légale'doit'ôtte fondée sur des procédés infaillibles et non sur des appré- ciations.
Au pis aller, 1a bonne foi da prévenu dans cette affaire est on ne peat plus évidente.
Or, le principe dit : pas d'intention, pu de punition.
Le jugement sera rendu a huita no.

div.head: Aux Sucreries
div.p: Les sucreries nous informent “que les ren- seignements dounés par notre correspon- dant occasionnel A.S. dans notre journal do Samedi dernier sont erronés. Les prix de re- vient dn snore indiqués pour les naines d’Abou Kourgas et Nag Hamadi sont tont b fait inexacts et non moins fantaisistes qne le prix de vente qne AS. prétend être de 25 frs. les cent kilos.
Ce cours de 25 frs. que mentionnent en effet les télégrammes s'entend du cours delà Bourse de Paris ayant trait a du sucre N 3 non raffine, livrable au cours de la prochaine cam- pagne betteravière.

Mais le sucre actuellement disponible est beaucoup plus cher. Nous ne nous trompons pas en indiquant que le cours actuel des sucres raffinés en Egypte est pour les pains d’environ 78 piastres le cantar et d'environ 63 piastres pour les granulés.
Certainement ces cours peuvent baisser puisque lu prévisions de récolte sont extrême- ment favorables en Europe, mais ils se main- tiendront plus que probablement au-dessus de 30 francs.
Notre journal ayant toujours a cour de renseigner le public très exactement et surtout impartialement, nous nous faisons un devoir de rectifier ce qu’avait écrit A.S."

div.head: SURVEY OF THE SUDAN. INTERVIEW WITH SLATIN PASHA.
div.p: A correspondent of the "Standard" lately obtained an interview with Sir Rudolph R. von Slatin Pasha, from whom he was able to gather a great deal of information of a sort which is scarcely available to the ordinary unofficial traveller o: student of world politics, the Inspector-General is, of course, an unim- peachable authority, and the very compre- hensive statement made by him should, therefore, prove of real and permanent value, In response to an opening question as to the general situation and outlook. Sir Rudolph said:— "I may say the situation in the Sudan is satisfactory, but the best way to demonstrate it is to give you some figures. Shortly after Lord Kitchener’s victory in 1898. the revenue of the Sudan was estimated at L.E 8,000, and L E. 35,000 were realised. The Budget of 1904 showed 'estimated revenue' L.E 469,000, while the ‘realised revenue' was L.E. 576,000. We are obeying the advice of Lord Cromer—the great statesman who has made the prosperity of Egypt and is now making that of the Sudan—that ‘low taxation should be tho key- stone of the political arch.

"As Inspector-General, it is my duty to travel over the whole Sudan, and to report on the situation. I have, too, to investigate com- plaints, and I can assure you that there have been very few cases in which people have complained that they were overtaxed, though he Sudanese certainly don't like paying taxes, Tout commencez nous!

"When we reoccupied the Sudan there were Fewer than -1,000 ‘sakias’ (water wheels) ; to- day there are over 10,000 ! Cultivation on rain land has increased enormously. Cotton, which was scarcely planted at all formerly, co vers to day an area of more than 95,000 acres in the different provinces. Herds and flocks are now very numerous. These results have been obtained through wise administra- tion.

"The Sirdar, General Sir Reginald Wingate is the right man for Governor-General of the Sudan. Not only is he the brave soldier who defeated and killed the Khalifa at Om Debere kat, and brought Mahdism to its end, but he is also an extremely good administrator. He talks Arabic fluently, which enables him, during his tours of inspection, to communicate directly with natives, instead of depending on an inter- preter. This is a very great advantage. He is the most kind-hearted man, but, at the -same time, strong-minded enough to force everybody to obey his orders ; and he has the gift of selecting his assistants, and putting them in their right places. As to his able and hard- working beads of departments and governors of provinces, it is unnecessary for me to praise them. The continuous progress of the Sudan speaks for them better than I could do. "Mr. Joseph Walton and Mr. Gibson Bowles came to Khartoum last winter and had a look round. Both expressed their thorough satis- faction with the state of affaire, and Mr. Bowles said to me, 'I confess I admire the work done by your subalterns.’ He used the word subaltern, as all governors and a great number of heads of department and inspectors are military officers, and comparatively young.

"But with regard, now, to the future, I am sure the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan is the land of the future. What we have to do is to improve communications and create a system of irrigation. Concerning communications, we are building a railway from the Red Sea to the Nile, joining the Haifa-Khartoum railway about 80 miles south of Berber. This line is built by Royal Engineer officers, under the Director of Railways, Lieut.-Colonel J. B. Macauley. Lord Cromer refused to import Indian labourers, as was first proposed, and insisted on our using natives of the country for the work. And we succeeded ! The lazy blacks, formerly loafers and runaway slaves, have now learnt to work steadily, and nomad Arabs, who had never worked since time im- memorial, gave a certain amount of help.

"The line, of over 320 miles length, will be finished, after two and a-half years’ work, and opened next spring. We shall have two ports —Old Suakin and the new Port Sudan, formerly called Sheikh el Bargh’ub which will be a splendid harbour. The straight and short débouché to the sea will enable us to export our products, such as gum, corn, cotton, etc. The cost of transport through Egypt is now too high, especially for heavy products, like gum and corn ; and traders, although they pay a very low price to the cultivators, state that it is hardly a profitable business to export Sudan products.

"We intend, after finishing the Red Sea- Nile railway, to build lines to Kassala, Gezira, and Kordofan. Meanwhile, we are trying to connect trade centres by trunk roads, on which we shall use motor-cars, and we are improv- ing other roads for animal transport The only difficulty is the want of money, and the Financial Secretary, Colonel Bernard, has to be always on the look out to meet the different demands with the money he has at his dis- posal.

”More difficult than communication is the question of irrigation. Although considerable progress was made during the past year in the direction of prospecting for minerals, believe the future of the Sudan lies in agricul- ture. Vast areas are still uncultivated, and ap- plications by important companies for permis- sion to buy land for agricultural purposes have to be refused, as we cannot grant them right of perennial irrigation. Egypt in all circum- stances must be sure of getting the necessary amount of water, and we are only allowed to take the surplus.

"We may take as much water as we like from July 15 until January 81 (as for 6 1/3) months the Nile water runs to waste into the sea), but after January 31 we have to get per- mission for every single pump of any size lift- ing water from the river. Mr. Dupuis, the Inspector-General of Irrigation in the Sudan, and his staff, under the supervision of Sir Wil- liam Garstin, the head of the Egyptian Public Works Department, are studying this most important question. Sir William Garstin, the highest authority on all irrigation matters, travelled during the last three years over the whole Sudan, examining all the waterways He even went to Uganda with the object of discovering means to increase the water supply. "Through Mr. Dupuis’s calculations, we know that if we make a simple canal from the Blue Nile to the White Nile, with a length of about 100 miles through fiat land, we shall be able to bring under cultivation an area of over three millions of acres of the best soil, which now lies fallow.

"Nevertheless, as I told you before, we are even now going ahead rapidly. Daring the rainy season the natives sow seed wherever water accumulates sufficiently to render the ground capable of bearing a crop.

"You ask me as to public security in the Sudan. You may believe me whom I tell you that you are just as safe in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan as you are in Europe, and perhaps more so ; and I may quote what I stated in one of my official reports :—'It is no exaggeration to say that, if it were not for the possible danger of attack by wild animals any individuals could pass unarmed through the whole country under the Sudan Government. Highway rob- bery is extremely rare, and there is com- paratively little thieving. If from time to time one or the other occurs, it is nearly always amongst natives, and not against the white man. Our police system is good, and the sheikh, and omdehs of villages and tribes, who are the pick of the population, are responsible for pubic security. Therefore I may say per- fect tranquillity and safety prevails in the Sudan.

"So much for the safety of individuals. Then, with regard to tribal affairs and the ad- ministration of Government orders, there were last year only two occasions on which public tranquillity was threatened.One man proclaim- ed himself as the 'Prophet Jesus.’ He had only eleven followers—a very small number for such a position and his appearance was by no means the execution of a well-prepared plan, but the unexpected action of a lunatic. The other case was that a continually drunken sheikh and some natives of a Nuba mountain refused to obey Government orders, and fired on a patrol.

“In both cases detachments were sent, and, after a short engagement and a few casualties, order was restored. However much we tray regret such forcible measures, it is sometimes important to show that we are able to enforce our authority, and that our orders have to be obeyed. Two cases are not many in a newly- conquered country consisting of eleven pro- vinces, of which some are greater than entire countries in Europe. You will have idea as of the Sudan if I tell you that one province out of eleven—Kordofan—is governed by some thirty British and Egyptian officials, and covers an area greater than the whole of France

"When I had to report officially on this sub ject, I wrote : 'Public security prevails, and, barring these two cases, Government orders have been and are carried out without any resistance. The inhabitants of the Sudan are convinced that the Government is able to maintain peace and to enforce prompt obe- dience to its orders.’ I don’t think I am committing an indiscretion if I tell you Lord Cromer’s criticism on my statement Lord Cromer said :—

“ I concur with the general principle that we should be able to maintain pesos, but this does not, to my mind, quite state the whole case. Justice, sound political and fiscal policy, backed by an adequate force, is the only way to govern the Sudan, or, indeed, any other country. I have but alight belief in the one without the other, whether the scene of action be St. Petersburg or Khartoum.' " The great statesman was very right Yes, I am proud to say our Government is just and its justice is recognised by every living soul in the Sudan—by redentary natives ant nomad Arabs. I never beard that even the losing party suspected one of our judges of having been influenced by private reasons in giving a decision or sentence. Never ! They appeal often, saying that the judge has misun- derstood the case—that individuals of bad character gave false evidence, or that they are able to produce new witnesses ; but there was never a remark about ‘injustice.’ In the eyes of the natives our judges are all Knights without fear and reproach’—as, indeed. they are.”

In reply to a question as to the popularity or otherwise of our administration, and the content of the people, the Inspector-General said : “ The people are every day gaining more confidence in the good intentions of the Government.

”They are convinced that we do our best to establish security in the country. Public wealth is increasing. In former days, under an earlier régime in the Sudan, every one wished to be considered poor. He was afraid that if he showed his wealth be would draw on himself the attention of the authorities, and be exposed to their despotic measures. Nowadays it is just the contrary. The native knows that with his wealth his influence as an individual increases, and that only a man of a certain amount of wealth is consulted by Government officials on public questions.

‘There is, of course, sometimes a little dis- satisfaction if an order is given which does not fit the immediate views and inclinations of the people, but they soon realise-that such ordi- nances are only given in the interest of public welfare- There may be some discontented in- dividuals who held prominent positions under the Dervish rule, and who are now powerless and ignored, but this does not apply to the public feeling. Especially is the sedentary popu- lation pleated with our system of administra- tion, and the prevailing security. Nomad Arabs are naturally last favorable to it I won’t say that they are discontented, or are onging for Dervish rule, or any other change. But nomad Arabs love a free and uncontrolled life, and we tie them down a good bit. "I had lately a meeting with the heads and sheikhs of nomad Arab tribes, and while talk- ing about the situation, and various other things, an old friend of mine, the head sheikh of an important tribe, asked me, quite confi- dentially :—Tell me—why have we to pay tribute to you? 'Because,' I answered, we are the masters of the country, which we con- quered—we established peace—and we protect you against all sorts of danger. Therefore, we have to keep a force, which has to be paid. Four tribute is, perhaps, a little assistance, but more a sign of loyalty.’

“ 'Oh, he said, T pay my tribute willingly, and I am loyal because you are the stronger. I don't mind if the lion takes toll out of my herd —that is his right, he is the king of the forests —but I won't pay tribute to be protected. I am man enough to protect myself ! Look, my dear friend and master,' he continued, with a sad smile, ‘you have taken all the spice out of our life. We Arabs are a fighting race—one day we were on a war footing, the next day living in peace with our neighbouring tribes. Coming back from a successful raid, I was received as a conqueror, and I was praised in song by the most beautiful women of my tribe. If I came back defeated, or if my enemy succeeded in taking away my herds, I bore my misfortune with dignity, thinking of the day of revenge... This was our traditional custom, and it has gone on for centuries. All my ancestors did so —why do you come and do away with our old and beloved habits? If I dare to fight now —even for the sake of my honor—1 risk being tried and put in gaol amongst common thieves and murderers.'

‘ I tried to argue with my old friend, and explained to him the advantages of peace and security, but I did not succeed in convincing him or his followers. When he asked me if we sometimes had war in Europe, I could not deny it, but explained to him that this was not the decision of a single individual, but a general necessity for reasons of state. He said : It's all the same ; yon have the sport— you have the fun of fighting.’ "And as we parted he shook hands with me, and his last words were : ‘Saladin ! You know I am loyal—but I am very sorry that you made me like a woman.'

I was long enough living amongst Arabs to understand their feeling in this matter, and most confess I have some sort of sympathy with them. . . . Please do not think that I am a warrior, and like ‘the fun of fighting.’ No ; I like peace—nearly as much as my cele- brated countrywoman Baroness Suttner, whose motto is, ’Die Waffen nieder.’ And as the Government made me responsible for the be- haviour of the nomad tribes, I hope to be able to prevent their falling back into their old barbaric habits.

"The greatest proof of confidenoe in the Government that the people give is the send- ing of their sons to Government schools. There are so many applications that we are forced to refuse a certain number, and so we are able to select our pupils. Of course the number of schools will be increased before long, so that every boy may get an elementary education. At the Gordon College at Khartoum members of families of religions influence are trained for schoolmasters and judges in the Maho- metan courts. Sons of sheikhs and important people of different tribes receive a general edu- cation, which will enable them to give sound advice to their relatives on public questions. Sons of officers and officials are taught to be Government clerks, surveyors, land measurers, etc., and other boys are sent to industrial workshops. Of coarse this is not a strict rule, but only the general line which is taken by Mr. Currie, who is the Director of Public Instruction.”

Entry by subscrip- tion and nomination as follows Subscription on 1st June P.T. 100, with P.T. 100 on nomination 1st October, and with a farther charge of P.T. 100, if left in after the 1st of January 1906.

THIRD WINTER MEETING. 2nd March 1906. Maidem Galloway : of P.T. 5,600, second horse to rewire P.T. 1,000, and third hone P.T. 600 out of the stakes. For Maiden Arab galloways. Weight for age and inches with penalties. Distance 6 furlongs. Entrance on the 1st October P.T. 960, or on the 1st February when the raw closes P.T. 500. SPRING SKYE MEETING. 16th March 1906. Ladies Bracelet : of P.T. 8,500, the nomi- nator of the winner to rewire a bracelet of P.T. 9,000, the nominator of the second horse an objet dart of P.T. 1,000 and the nominator of the third horse an objet dart of P.T. 500. For Arab horses that have never won a raw of any description (at the time of entry) Gym- khanas' excepted. Weight for age with penal- ties. Galloways allowed 7 lbs. ponies one stone. Distance about f mile. Entrance on 1st Janu- ary P.T. 160, or on 1st March when the raw closes P.T. 300. The Possessor of two nominations, in any of the above raws, has got the right to nominate also a third hone, in that raw, at the time the entries dose for all raws of that Meeting, by paying double entrance foe. div.head: Municipalte D'Alexandrie
div.p: La Municipalite croit devoir rappeler an public que d'apres l'art. 9 du decret de 1884 sur l'impot de la propriete batie, tout proprie- taire faisant de nouvelles constructions, addi- tions ou retranchementa a ses immeubles doit sous peine de double imposition, aviser la Municipalite par ecrit sous pli recommande avant le 15 novembre de chaque annce.

A la suite de nombreuses reclamations pour degrevement d'amendes infligees pour non-avis de nouvelles constructions, la Delegation Mu- nicipale a decide qu'ancune reclamation a ce sujet sous pretexte d'ignorance de la loi ne sera prise eu consideration. Le Vice-President (signe Ambroise A. Ralli Alexandria, le 25 Septembre 1905
